div.p:
Tthe payments which
you will oblige me
by making for Agnes
are as follows:

One hundred & twenty
pounds a year to
Madame Hocédé,
and probably the best
way of doing it would
be for an arrangement
to be made in Paris
by which she could draw
it quarterly - and also
one Pound a month
as pocket money
for Agnes.

A sum will also
be required for
Music & German
masters and for
washing, and this
Agnes will ascer-
tain and give you
information.

She has clothing
enough to last till
she goes out of
mourning and
then she will consult
Mrs Murray as to
what dresses she
may need, and
you will be good
enough to take
Mrs Murray's opinion
as sufficient
authority for the
amount necessary
to be spent in dress.

In any question that
might arise you
will find Mr Oswell's
judgment with your
own sufficient for
guidance: Mr Young's
opinion will always
be reasonable and
of value. But in all
cases I am sure that
you will act for the
best or what at the
time seems to be so and
for that I shall be
satisfied and thankful
whatever may be the
result.
